body: @markusweimer posted a few things to discuss, please let me know what you think. Thanks!
@afchung @dkm2110 @markusweimer I have addressed your review comments. Please have another look and sign off if you think it is OK before Dhruv test it on cluster. Thanks!
Taking a second pass.
Sorry for pointing this out a bit late, but I'm confused by what the item actually aims to do. Why are there changes in IMRU at all?
I'm done with another pass. I'll take a look at the tests once I understand what this PR is really trying to address.
@jwang98052 why was the PR rebased?

@afchung The purpose of the PR is to make sure the tasks are disposed after close is called. When I was working on the test cases, I find a scenario where the message in the CloseEvent can be null, but IMRUTask Close handlers don't handle that case, it is a bug. Without fixing it, the test won't pass. Therefore I made some minor changes in the IMRUTask close handler. In your review, you pointed the two close handlers have the same code, therefore introducing a code refactor in the task close handler.
@afchung I have addressed your comments. Please have another look.
This seems to pass consistently on Jenkins now. @jwang98052 would be great if you can merge. Thanks!

@afchung I was to merge with REEF-1408 which contains IMRU testing and some bug fixes that would impact the IMRUdriver testing. The testing is needed when I make any changes during the review, I want to make sure the code still pass the tests. As you were the only one who made the review at that time, and this PR will have a long review chain in future I believe, so I think the earlier to rebase the better. Sorry for the inconvenience. 

In fact,  I also want to merge with REEF-1423 once it is in as it fixed a bug that also impact IMRUDriver fault tolerant behavior.

@dkm2110 REEF-1408 contains tests that can pass for both old and new IMRU drivers. It ensures no regression is introduced. It also contains close event testing for IMRU Tasks which has been updated. REEF-1451 is opened to track the scenario testing where we will add more tests for failed cases.

If we wanted a test, I suggest to file a separate JIRA that links back to this one. The change at hand fixes a bug and should go in before we have a test for this edge case.

Chatted with out client, their scenarios is 
Request Evalautor,
call SubmitContextAndServiceAndTask on IAllocatedEvaluator then crash. 

That means the Evalautor is not physically exist yet. Who sets evaluator state to FAILED or KILLED?

> That means the Evalautor is not physically exist yet. Who sets evaluator state to FAILED or KILLED? 

YARN. It could be that the machine we have the container allocation on crashed before we launched the Evaluator process on it.

@jwang98052 note that we have changed the behavior of an `Exception` occurring in `TaskCloseHandler`. This may change the behavior in fault tolerance, when you are forcing Tasks to close. I've modified the tests to fit the behavior, but there might be things I'm missing. Please take a closer look. Thanks!
@jwang98052 for the motivation of the change, please read the JIRA. Thanks!
It does break the current implementation of IMRU fault tolerant. I have opened REEF-1466 for the solution/discussion.

When I add one more package in a project, the packages.config for that project is generated again. We need to manually move that to the global one. 
Also after I added a new package to a project, the solution auto generated app.config file for each project. That is annoying.
@dkm2110 would be great if you could take a look. Thanks!

@jwang98052 As discussed over on JIRA, the reliance on exceptions thrown by a `StopHandler` to stop a Task does not work, regardless of whether or not this gets merged. Hence, shall we go ahead with this change?
I've done another pass.

I did half a pass. My concern is that the `IMRUDriver` doesn't seem to loose complexity as part of the move to the various `Manager` classes. In fact, it seems to be gaining complexity and state.

I was hoping for a significant reduction in complexity when we do things via Rx operators. For instance, we could have something like this:

```
class ContextManager: Observer<ActiveContext>, Observer<FailedContext>, Observable<IEnumerable<ActiveContext>>
{
}
```

This class receives all events as they pertain to contexts and emits the `IEnumerable<ActiveContext>` whenever it has received enough `ActiveContext` events. Similarly, it could have access to a `IMRUStateManager` which keeps tabs on the overall state of the system. If an event violates the state machine assumption, `ContextManager` would call `OnError` for its subscribers.

Similar approaches can the thought of for `EvaluatorManager`, `TaskManager`, ...

Maybe I am being naive, but this approach should encapsulate the mutable state (and therefore complexity) of IMRUDriver into smaller units, which makes it much easier to test and debug. Right now, I fear we use the various `*Manager` classes as collection objects only, which keeps all of the logic in the Driver.
@afchung left one comment. Otherwise LGTM.
I again see that appveyor build is failing.
I completed a pass.

If REEF-1469 is going to be merged first, this PR needs to be rebased as there is no way to merge with the big conflict. You can give me high level comments for now and expecting not to see the delta after the rebase.
@johnyangk

It's a pretty large PR, but most of the code here overlaps with the LocalRuntime code with tweaks for the StandaloneRuntime. I've tested with my machine, and it worked. Still, I don't feel completely confident about the PR, since I'm not fully confident with all REEF components, and there are some implementations that still feels like they could be improved. Therefore, any kind of suggestions will be welcome.
Thanks! I'll take a look.

Thanks! I started a review and noticed that there are many classes which are (almost) verbatim copies from the local runtime. That seems unfortunate. Can't we reuse those exact classes in this runtime as well?
@markusweimer Yup, will do. I wasn't sure if those duplicate code were to be recreated to prevent confusion about the folder structures or to simply reuse them, but thanks for clarifying!
Thanks @markusweimer for reviewing! I'll come back after you're done. :)
Those files that are worth looking at in the meanwhile will be `driver/NodeListManager` and `process/SshProcess`.

@dkm2110 @jwang98052 @markusweimer thanks for the review! I've addressed your comments, please have another look. The Appveyor build failures are known failures and the code change here should not have affected the failed tests.

@markusweimer I thought about the way you mentioned during the design. Basically EvaluatorManager is also the AllocatedEvaluatorHandler and FailedEvaluatorHandler, TaskManager is also RuningTaskHandler and  FailedTaskHandler and responsible for submit tasks, etc. 

The pros are, driver is simple, and the managers can be reused in other fault tolerant if they are abstracted good enough. 

The cons are all those managers need to know each other. For example, in FailedEvaluatorHandler, EvaluatorManager needs to talk to TaskManager for the failed task wrapped in the FailedEvaluator. With the current approach, driver knows every one and control the system state. All the managers are responsible for managing their own entities, they don't talk to each other and they also don't know the system state. 

I guess one way to avoid the cross references is for them to observe each other as you suggested. Like TaskManager observes Context manager, TaskManager also needs to observe EvaluatorManager so that FailedEvaluator onNext will trigger a call in the TaskManager to record FailedTask wrapped inside Failedevaluator,etc. 

For the lock, should all the managers (event handlers) share the same lock? Currently, all the managers are marked as NotThreadSafe and driver has one lock for all the handlers.

@markusweimer After REEF-1466 is resolved, we should be fine with this change. In REEF-1466, we will use cancellation token to let the task return properly from close handler instead of throw exception.
@afchung with this change, I would expect IMRUCloseTaskTest fail as it throws exception in task close handler and expecting FailedTask if the task cannot return properly. I don't know how it passed test somehow. I have updated this test in REEF-1466.

@wonook Please make sure your code passes Checkstyle and other code style checks which are part of the build. Right now you can see Travis CI failed because of Checkstyle error:

```
[ERROR] src/main/java/org/apache/reef/examples/hello/HelloREEFStandalone.java:[54,56] (misc) FinalParameters: Parameter nodeListFileName should be final.
[ERROR] Failed to execute goal org.apache.maven.plugins:maven-checkstyle-plugin:2.17:check (validate) on project reef-examples: You have 1 Checkstyle violation. -> [Help 1]
```
@markusweimer @jwang98052 I've addressed your comments, please have another look. Thanks!
LGTM to merge
I've addressed the reviews so far!

Would it make more sense to take those classes used both by the `reef-runtime-local` and `reef-runtime-standalone` in another package, something like `reef-runtime-common` or something similar? It doesn't feel right for `reef-runtime-standalone` to have dependencies on other runtime modules.
Yes, that would be good. While we are at it, we could also define a clean interface between that common runtime and its implementations.
@jwang98052 I've addressed your comments, please have another look. Thanks!
LGTM, I'll test and merge
